content.question: A small sphere is launched horizontally with a speed <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> toward a target a horizontal distance <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> away. The sphere lands on the target that is at height <math alttext="H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> below the height from which the sphere was launched. If the sphere were launched again, but with a speed <math alttext="2 v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> , how high above the target would the sphere have to be launched horizontally to hit the same target, still a horizontal distance <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> away?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
